--- title: "Week-4: Code-along" author: "Tang Ching Xian" date: "31-08-2023" output: html_document: df_print: paged ```{r setup, include=TRUE} knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE) ``` # II. Code to edit and execute using the Code-along.Rmd file
## A. Data Wrangling
### 1. Loading packages (Slide #16) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} # Load package tidyverse library(tidyverse) ``` ### 2. Loading data-set (Slide #16) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=FALSE} # Read data from the hotels.csv file and assign it to a variable named, "hotels" read.csv("hotels.csv") hotels <- read_csv("hotels.csv") ``` ### 3. List names of the variables in the data-set (Slide #19) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} names(hotels) ``` ### 4. Glimpse of contents of the data-set (Slide #20) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} glimpse(hotels) ```
## B. Choosing rows or columns
### 5. Select a single column (Slide #24) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} # View only lead_time (number of days between booking and arrival) select(hotels, lead_time) ``` ### 6. Select multiple columns (Slide #25) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} # View lead_time, agent and market_segment select(hotels, lead_time,agent,market_segment) ``` ### 7. Arrange entries of a column (Slide #28) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} # Rearranged entries of lead_time arrange(hotels, lead_time) ``` ### 8. Arrange entries of a column in the descending order (Slide #30) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} #Rearrange entries in the descending order arrange(hotels, desc(lead_time)) ``` ### 9. Select columns and arrange the entries of a column (Slide #31) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} arrange( select(hotels, lead_time), desc(lead_time) ) ``` ### 10. Select columns and arrange the entries of a column using the pipe operator (Slide #37) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% select(lead_time) %>% arrange(desc(lead_time)) ``` ### 11. Pick rows matching a condition (Slide #44) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% filter(children >= 1) %>% select(hotel, children) ``` ### 12. Pick rows matching multiple conditions (Slide #46) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% filter(children >= 1, hotel=="City Hotel") %>% select(hotel, children) ``` ### 13. Non-conditional selection of rows: sequence of indices (Slide #49) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% slice(1:5) ``` ### 14. Non-conditional selection of rows: non-consecutive/specific indices (Slide #50) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% slice(1,3,5) ``` ### 15. Pick unique rows using distinct() (Slide #52) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% distinct(hotel) ```
## C. Creating new columns
### 16. Creating a single column with mutate() (Slide #56) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% mutate(little_ones = children + babies) %>% select(hotel, little_ones,children,babies) ``` ### 17. Creating multiple columns with mutate() (Slide #58) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% mutate(little_ones = children + babies, average_little_ones = mean(little_ones)) %>% select(hotel, little_ones,children,babies) ```
## D. More operations with examples
### 18. count() to get frequencies (Slide #60) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% count(market_segment) ``` ### 19. count() to get frequencies with sorting of count (Slide #61) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% count(market_segment, sort = TRUE) ``` ### 20. count() multiple variables (Slide #62) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% count(hotel, market_segment) ``` ### 21. summarise() for summary statistics (Slide #63) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} # mean average daily rate for all bookings hotels %>% summarise(mean_adr = mean(adr)) ``` ### 22. summarise() by using group_by to find mean (Slide #64) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} # mean average daily rate for all booking at city and resort hotels hotels %>% group_by(hotel) %>% summarise(mean_adr = mean(adr)) ``` ### 23. summarise() by using group_by to get count (Slide #65) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} # Count of bookings at city and resort hotels hotels %>% group_by(hotel) %>% summarise(count = n()) ``` ### 24. summarise() for multiple summary statistics (Slide #67) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% summarise( min_adr = min(adr), mean_adr = mean(adr), median_adr = median(adr), max_adr = max(adr) ) ``` ### 25. select(), slice() and arrange() (Slide #68) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% select(hotel, lead_time) %>% slice(1:5) %>% arrange(lead_time) ``` ### 26. select(), arrange() and slice() (Slide #69) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% select(hotel, lead_time) %>% arrange(lead_time) %>% slice(1:5) ``` ### 27. filter() to select rows based on conditions (Slide #73) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% filter( adults == 0, children >= 1 ) %>% select(adults, babies, children) ``` ### 28. filter() to select rows based on complicated conditions (Slide #74) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% filter( adults == 1, children >= 1 | babies >=1) %>% select(adults, babies, children) ``` ### 29. count() and arrange() (Slide #76) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% count(market_segment) %>% arrange(desc(n)) ``` ### 30. mutate(), select() and arrange() (Slide #77) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% mutate(little_ones = children + babies) %>% select(children, babies, little_ones) %>% arrange(desc(little_ones)) ``` ### 31. mutate(), filter() and select() (Slide #78) ```{r, eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE} hotels %>% mutate(little_ones = children + babies) %>% filter( little_ones >= 1, hotel == "City Hotel" ) %>% select(hotel, little_ones) ```
